Adds an extra mile to your hike around the lake.
Entrance is located at the end of a residential street.

This loop trail is out in the farther reaches of the Haverford Reserve grounds. Start with the Blue Route Trail, and then just after coming under the interstate overpass, bear right. The trail soon forks, take either path on the way out. After crossing through a gap in the old railroad roadbed, the two paths then rejoin and immediately fork again, in a sort of four-way intersection. Again take either path, just be alert to avoid confusion as you'll encounter the same four-way intersection again when looping back around.
ELK

This steel-blue-blazed trail winds through the periphery of the Haverford Reserve trail network, accessible only via the Old Gray Trail and the Meadow Trail. It has several alternative paths in spots and partially overlaps the disc golf course which can be confusing. Segments are fairly close to I-476 with road noise audible.

This short orange-blazed trail starts to the right side of the CREC at Haverford Reserve and runs past a small garden area and then beside the disc golf course to terminate at the Meadow Trail. The Veterans Trail is a parallel alternate for a portion.

This green-blazed trail runs a short distance through Haverford Reserve, branching off from the Northbrook Trail just behind the CREC and then rejoining it later. It provides close access to the brook with a pleasant wooden bridge.

trail_name: Tuscarora Trail: Waggoners Gap to Sterretts Gap
description:
This is the section of the Tuscarora Trail (TT) from Waggoners Gap in the west to Sterretts Gap in the east. From the west, the trail starts at the Audubon Hawk Watch parking lot.  A short side trail leads from the TT up talus slopes to overlook with good views south across the Cumberland Valley.  

Past the Hawk Watch, the trail enters the F.J. Reineman Wildlife sanctuary and proceeds east along the northern bench of the mountain.  This section of trail is particularly rocky.

The trail eventually comes to a junction with old Longs Gap Road and bears north onto in and descends (to the south, the road leads a short distance to good views of Cumberland Valley).  Near the base of the mountain, the TT bears east off-road and ascends back to the northern bench of the mountain.

Just before bearing north and descending along the power line cut, the trail passes a talus slope with good views to the south.  At the base of the mountain, the trail bears east of the power line cut onto dirt road near a cabin and proceeds to PA-34 (Spring Road).  The trail then bears south on a road and ascends along the shoulder to Sterretts Gap.

Roam along the Slateford Loop Trail ready to experience beautiful farmlands and dense, colorful Pennsylvanian hardwood forests.

Starting at the Arrow Island Trail South Parking Area off National Park Dr., travel north along the Arrow Island Spur and turn left at the junction with the Arrow Island Trail. Follow the Arrow Island trail (heading west) for a short while until it reaches a T intersection with the Slateford Loop Trail. 

At this point, visitors can hike whichever direction they choose, taking note that this trail is a series of two loops joined by a central connector. Those wishing for a shorter excursion can remain on the eastern loop, while those wishing for more time in the woods can hike both loops. 

While on trail, keep your eyes peeled for the remains of a bygone slate quarry and a historic farm which both exist today as weathered, brown structures. The trail is somewhat rolling, but not overly strenuous.

If you're taking the larger of the two loops, note that you may have to navigate a small portion of the southern extent on a little-used portion of National Park Drive.

The trail starts across the street from the parking lot for Pie Traynor Field. Following along the hillside for the first half of the trail, you'll be on doubletrack trail, heavily traveled with walkers and dogs.  

The second half of the trail becomes a singletrack dream with a slight uphill the whole way. You'll weave in and around trees, hike minor switchbacks, and have views of the surrounding hillside as you traverse the opposite side of the hill you started.

Midnite Ridge Trail runs along the slopes between Baltimore Road and Thompson Hollow Road. The trail is a mix of narrow singletrack and some sections of doubletrack that starts with a steep climb from the west before it levels out through the forest and clear cuts higher up. Part way through the trail, hikers will encounter an area of loose "doll head" rocks that make for slightly awkward footing.

Journey along the Arrow Island Trail for a pleasant hike through second-growth hardwood forests to a scenic viewpoint overlooking Arrow Island.

Visitors to the trail have the option to park at either the southern parking area off National Park Drive, or the northern parking area off Route 611 near the Arrow Island Overlook.

Starting at the southern parking area, follow the short Arrow Island Spur to a junction with the Arrow Island Trail. Continue right along the trail, keeping your eyes peeled for remnants of the vibrant cultural history embedded in the forests along the Delaware. 

Back in the beginning of the 20th century, numerous hotels and tourist attractions were located along this stretch of river. 

If you're lucky, you just might see the remains of two different periods of occupation along the trail: first a series of old farm fences, and second a collection of stone supports that once upheld a raucous casino. 

Lastly, bring your eyes up to the towering cliffs above the trail for an exciting peek into prime peregrine falcon territory. For those with access to a pair of binoculars, this trail presents the perfect opportunity to use them! 

Upon reaching the trail's end, hop across the road to the Arrow Island Overlook for stunning views of the Delaware River and Arrow Island.

This 20-mile trail follows the Perkiomen Creek from Oaks (at the Schuylkill Tr to Green Lane Park).  The trail is mostly crushed stone with a few paved paths.  The majority of the trail is wide enough for several people to hike alongside each other.  

The trail begins at  the Schuylkill Tr in Oaks. but there is no parking at this point.  There is a parking lot for Lower Perkiomen Valley Park on Mill Rd,(on trail, but 1 mile from S end). Entire section from parking South to the Schuylkill Tr is paved.  In this section, there are picnic tables, fire pits, and pavilions.  There are athletic fields used for organized soccer and ultimate events.  This section is wooded with cut grass undercover.

To the North, the trail and creek cross under Egypt Road Bridge and follow the Perkiomen upstream.  For approx 1 mile, the trail remains a wide paved surface.  When this large surface reaches Upper Indian Head Rd (the first road encountered, and blocked with yellow bollards), the trail turns left/away from the creek.  It will follow road briefly until a gravel path on the right approximately midway up first rise.  Go right as the path dives through some wooded areas.  This next section will be a mix of crushed gravel path and hard pack dirt/rock path.

There will be two hazardous road crossings.  Each crossing carries the trail at an angle across the road somewhat in a hill section of the road with limited sight distance for drivers.  Although the crossings are well marked, traffic generally moves quickly and drivers may not heed the trail signs.

After these two crossings, there are few hazards.  The remaining road crossings are either protected with signals or have plenty of visibility for trail users and drivers. The trail passes through Collegeville in the form of sidewalks and paths between buildings.It passes close to a brewery, a diner, and several other dining options.  North of Collegeville, a large portion of the trail is paved until it reaches Central Perkiomen Valley Park, another picnic and recreation facility with parking bathroom facilities.   The Skippack Trail offers a side trip to the Village of Skippack.

To North, trail is mostly crushed gravel with some pavement. It passes old Mill House, Pennypacker Mills Historic Site, and Green Lane Park, offering swimming, boating, and camping facilities.  Visit  montcopa.org/index.aspx?nid… for camping, boating, fishing and more trails in Green Lane Park

Mid State Trail (MST)

This trail can start at either the spillway to the east or at the entrance to the lodge at the north end. You immediately begin by climbing (from either direction) before the trail plateaus into a rolling, mile long, upper stretch. Typically muddy with "streams" running down the trail at the ascents/descents, this trail can be an interesting adventure.

Also, it's a great addition to the Red/Blue Blaze, which creates a loop around the lodge.  However, it is not an easy 9'ish mile loop, with lots of ups and downs, doubling back, and little flat terrain.

Enter this trail on the left from the W Circuit Road. It doesn't feature a particularly steep climb, but instead rolls gently up and down. A couple of intersections allow hikers to exit on the E Circuit Road. 

Keep on straight, the trail connects to the larger and milder Lower Panther Hollow Trail. This one is often quite muddy, so use caution!

Access the trail from a small gravel parking area.  The short loop follows around a small stream dotted with educational signs. Visitors will enjoy the gentle and flat grades, and the stream creates an enjoyable ambiance. This is a great way to really feel as though you're getting away from it all!

The trail can be reached from Buckskin Trail or from Nichols Road. The trail itself is a split between doubletrack and singletrack, with the majority of it on singletrack. It runs relatively flat with slight rises and descents.

From the southern end, you'll have a chance to look out over the valley, albeit under canopy and with plenty of undergrowth.

When traveled from east to west, this is a challenging, rocky singletrack with some sharp, quick climbs. If the technical sections don't wear you out, the climbs will. Once you hit the powerline, follow that down the fire road all the way to right before the end where it goes up a little bit and comes out onto Sulphur Springs Rd.

When utilized from west to east, it is a fireroad climb to the powerline and then a rocky technical downhill to Shaffers Trail.

Start at the Bald Eagle Launch in Howard. The trail goes through a heavily wooded area with lots of  creek crossings and rock gardens. It remains within 20 ft or so of the lake shore on the way out (but views of the lake are limited by the heavy growth). The trail is a flattened lollipop shape. 

The second half is a loop that follows the lake edge on the way out, crosses under the train tracks and continues through the woods, paralleling the train tracks back to Park Rd. Follow Park Rd for a few hundred yards to get to the crossover back under the train tracks to connect with the first part of the trail. Retrace your steps on the first half of Lakeview Trail to return to the parking lot.

If you like rocky trails then this one if for you!

Starting from the top of the trail, access is available from Nichol Road. Hikers will travel through a 20 foot open field with power lines. Shortly after, an intersection in the trail can take you to another campground (to the right) or take a hard left and continue on Heron Trail. This is where the downhill starts.

Tough to hike when muddy, this section runs hard downhill following groundwater streams, until eventually connecting with the Wetlands Trail.

Typically, hikers take this trail starting from the south entrance off of Raccoon Mountain Trail, and heading to the northern terminus on Schuler Woods Trail. However, this trail can be taken either way. 

The southern entrance has a small tube with gravel spread over it. Enter and head up a small hill and enjoy the singletrack through the dip. You'll run into an intersection in an open grassy area, where a long forgotten trail used to meet. While the trail has been abandoned, its remnants remain. Stick to the well defined trail downhill, and you'll soon be on your way! 

This trail then intersects with Schuler Woods Trail. Go right to Remington Access Road or left toward the stone bridge.

The Jeep Trail Connector starts out as singletrack but ends as doubletrack. When taken west to east, you can reach the powerlines and go left down the powerlines to the dirt road, or you can head up the powerlines to Sulphur Springs Road.

Turn off Remington Access Road to the left onto Middleton Road. It's pretty much all doubletrack but it runs like singletrack. This trail has some slow grades with some slight downhill mixed in. It travels from covered tree areas to some open, sunny areas, and back and forth. Once you get to a split, stay right to continue on "Lower Middleton" or slight left to go "Upper Middleton Road". 

Once you take the 90 degree turn it climbs up a bit then you come to a dirt road called Sunnyside Road; head down that to go back, or turn around and go back the way you came.

This gravel connector trail is pleasant to use in either direction.

Start in at the yellow gate off of Gap Road and head up the long doubletrack climb. This connector will end with a yellow gate at the exit. 

To access other trails such as the No Name Trail, the Webster Trail, or Mile Run Road, turn onto the Fourth Gap Road for a short ways.

This rail trail technically connects Coraopolis with the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP) in McKeesport; although, a section is under development around Jefferson Hills.  

The trail itself is a mix of cinder and paved path. It gently climbs the first 10 miles to the foot of Robinson Town Center. From here's the trail dips and dives, never at more than a 1% grade, through the South Hills. 

The trail offers access to Panhandle Trail, which brushes by Settlers Cabin State Park, and the trails at South Park (South Park Connection to Montour Trail).  

For access to GAP trail:
Unfortunately, the trail is incomplete past South Park. To continue to McKeesport, hikers will need to follow Piney Fork Road making a right at the current southern/eastern trail terminus. This will take hikers through a narrow tunnel before a 4-way intersection where the rail trail picks up again on the road's edge. After a quarter mile, hikers will cross Gill Hall Road, ending the roadside rail section, and follow Peters Creek Road for roughly 3 miles. After crossing route 51 and staying on Peters Creek Road, hikers will find the Montour Trail East section dipping into Clairton. 

In Clairton, make a right on North State Street and cross Clairton-Glassport bridge. Follow Ohio Avenue north making your way through Glassport and eventually over the 5th Ave bridge into McKeesport. Most of this section is over bike shared roads with sidewalks available. The full length of Montour Trail to McKeesport is around 60 miles.

Summit Trail is a very rough jeep/access trail that runs across the top of the ridge. While this particular trail is nothing special, it can be used to access trails on both sides of the Water Authority. It can be taken in either direction.

Access the trail from the park office. The trail starts as a grassy smooth track to your immediate right as you enter the woods near Route 18 and the park entrance. The trail climbs and winds its way to a stretch of pine trees that cover the trail with soft needles. At the end of the trail you'll intersect with the Mineral Springs Loop Trail. Heading right takes you over Heritage Trail and the waterfall. Left takes you downhill back to the park office.

This connector trail runs in two directions from the parking lot at its midpoint. To the north, a dirt road trail follows along an elevation contour with very little elevation change. Through the trees you can make out the mountain ridge which Painter Rock Trail follows. One cemetery and an individual grave headstone dating to 1896 are seen along the trail.

To the south, a singletrack trail takes hikers downhill towards Roaring Run Trail. This section is technical and has a significant descent just before reaching Roaring Run.

This urban trail is a loop around the reservoir covered with crushed limestone. The park itself is heavily used, with most people sticking to the road. This leaves the trail a little less used, oddly.

The trail itself is nondescript. It does offer a breeze in summer, as it sits atop Highland Park. The surrounding area includes a nice children's play area, the Pittsburgh Zoo, a dog park (new as of 2016), and more singletrack trail; enough to get 3-4 miles of exercise in.
Less of a trail, and more of a road, this trail is somewhat unremarkable. In general, it is a low-grade, gravel access road that gets you to most of the trails at the Water Authority.

The trail consists of educational signage and opportunities to get close to the lake in more secluded areas. However, it's mostly in a low lying area and may be prone to flooding or retaining water after heavy rains.

The wooded section, opposite the lake side, passes over pine soft trail sections.  

Keep you're eyes peeled for changes in direction because the trail is not well-worn making it easy to get off trail.

From the corner of Middleton Road and Sunnyside Road head back down the wide open dirt access road. There are a few intersections, just don't turn onto any that are marked no trespassing; they will lead you to the reservoir which is a no trespassing zone. 

Once you get to the steepest descent towards the end, start looking out for a gate that goes across the road. After that, there is a tough climb out of the hollow that will put you back to the top of Remington Access Road.

You can hike in either direction.

The trail can be taken in either direction.

This trail is affectionately known as "The Mud Trail" for a reason. The section nearest Remington Access Road has had some drainage culverts installed and is in decent shape. The Quarry Trail exits on this dryer portion and is often traveled.  The portion that connects to Raccoon Trail is a perennially wet trail.  

Not often used, but fun if you want the mud. In winter, a nice frozen connector.

NOTE:  This portion of trail is not associated with the longer-distance Schuylkill River Trail and not part of that system. This may become an alternate path for the longer trail, but the official Schuylkill River Trail is located on the Chester County or western side of the river.  Instead, this trail is part of the proposed "Schuylkill East Trail" which would be a similar long distance trail. Though this section is complete, the longer trail is still in progress (or possibly just in planning).

This trail follows the Schuylkill River on the Montgomery County side of the river. From the parking area at Lock 60 Park, cross the small footbridge over the canal and turn left. Go past the gate and follow a small footpath upriver.  

In the beginning, this will be a grassy path. Along your left there will be the remnants of moorings for the canal and an older generating station. At the upriver end of the canal is Black Rock Dam, which is about 1/3 mile into the route. 

Depending on river levels, it may be difficult to proceed beyond the dam. Normally, the far right edge of the dam is exposed and passable. From here, the trail becomes more gravel/rock bed and narrower with a few spots of mud and small water crossings. At the upriver end of the trail, you'll come to Upper Schuylkill Valley Park and Wildlife Center operated by Montgomery County. There is also a picnic and parking area here.

This trail leads uphill from the parking lot at the WMWA visitor lot. Hikers can visit the foundations of the old Remington Estate near the top of the trail. The end is a slight downhill to Remington Access Road. This trail is heavily used by hikers and runners, please keep bikes and dogs off.

Start the trail from the parking lot at Lower Perkiomen Valley Park. From the parking lot, head back on Mill Rd towards Egypt Road. The trail crosses over the Perkiomen Trail and Perkiomen Creek on the Egypt Rd Bridge. After crossing the bridge, look for bollards denoting where the path passes through a wooden fence. 

The trail passes through a meadow offering opportunities for birding and wildflower observation before crossing the Mine Run (bridge). Here, the trail enters a wooded area and begins a steep ascent. A few marked side trails are off to the right following Mine Run into the Perkiomen. As the trail levels out, the remains of an old copper and lead mine will be on your left, (with an interpretive sign). The paved trail continues on and reaches the edge of a large field. As the trail turns a corner, a large bird blind is positioned facing the field. 

If you wish to visit the Museum (Audubon's house) and Raptor Center (next to the house), follow the dirt path across the field and turn to the right. You can return to the loop trail by following the driveway until it crosses the trail just before exiting the property at the corner of Audubon Road and Pawlings Road. 

The paved loop trail continues around the edge of the field and turns to follow Pawlings Road. The trail runs alongside Pawlings Road for a bit. On the non-road side of the trail look for more birds and forest restoration activities (and more interpretive waysides). There will be one short descent and climb when the trail crosses Old Mill Road. The trail continues on to cross US 422 via the Pawlings Rd Bridge (concrete barriers isolate the trail and vehicular traffic, fencing prevents leaping from the bridge). 

The trail joins the Schuylkill River Trail - Conshohocken to Parkersford at the Pawlings Road Trail Parking area.
This trail starts near the cabin area of Black Moshannon State Park and ends at the Indian Trail, crossing the Hay Road Trail in between.

The trail system is easily accessed from the Kentuck Campground area, including the Kentuck Trail and Beech Loop Trail.  

The system of trails consists of mowed paths through open fields and slightly wooded sections. The trail mapped above is the perimeter of the trail system. Trails are not blazed aside from markings posted at intersections; however, it would not be possible to get off trail as the grasses are tall in summer and the paths are obvious.

Braddock Trail is a "rail-trail" walking trail that provides access to Frick Park's eastern trails and connects the park to the Regent Square neighborhood at two points off S. Braddock Ave near the Frick Park Tennis courts on the Northern End and via Allanby Ave on the southern end, near the parkway.
The loop is useful in connecting between Sproul XC Ski Trail and Beech Trail. It is singletrack and groomed. Beginning at the campground, the trail is used by campers with children and dogs.

The trail starts out as a doubletrack fire road and then turns into some smooth rolling doubletrack on top. The hill has lots of rock and is more like a logging road than a trail, and it gets steep in spots.
This trail connects the yellow-blazed Horseshoe Trail with an unidentified trail (appears to be formerly used as the Horseshoe Trail) to create a loop. Nice hike, however there are no views.

This climb begins from the intersection with the Mountain View Trail and continues to the intersection near Willow Springs and the Lookout Loop. 

This is a dirt and gravel road that provides the only way to climb to the very top of the mountain other than using the paved road. Multi-directional, this trail is also used as a way down for the more mellow hikers. The climb starts off gradually and gets steeper after a left bend before really kicking up to high grades at the top.

The trail can be accessed from the park road or Cabin Hollow Trail. Heading south, the trail is a long descent with a steep section around half way. The trail is also rocky and root-ridden, much like the entire trail system.
Heavy overgrowth including many thorns. Wear gaiters and/or pants.

Enter the trail off Brown road or from the Golf Course Trail (Orange Blaze). From the Orange Loop stay right and the singletrack trail will lead you around the edge of the grass field before entering the woods again.

Follow the trail (there are several un-blazed trails available to runners and mountain bikers) along the hillside and around the gully.  The final stretch before jumping on to Brown road crosses over a small creek/marshy area.  Once on Brown road, go right to head to North Park area.

This trail is part of a larger plan to eventually have 17 miles of interconnected trails hooking into the White Clay Creek PA side. Currently, it isn't done yet, but this section can be connected with another short trail to get a nice 5-mile hike in. 

Unfortunately, this trail isn't well maintained. It's a shame since it has such potential. If you want to see about helping maintain this trail, I'm sure a little leg work each month would yield great results.

The trail takes a series of stairs to climb above the falls. The end of the trail places you directly above the falls with a steep descent to the stream.

Tracking from the intersection with Roller Coaster Trail and Three Springs Trail to Chappells Field Trail, this is a doubletrack trail that is used to connect the bottom of the Mountain View - Roller Coaster Section, Rock-n-Ridge #4 , Rock-n-Ridge #3 and Rock-n-Ridge #2 (in that order) before finally working over to Chappells Field.

The doubletrack is flat and free of obstacles, making this a good warm up on the way to some great singletrack, or as a place for the inexperienced to learn.

This trail runs between North Trails and the Spur Trail. Following above a stream along a ravine hillside, the trail crosses several minor streams using currently broken bridges. Hence, the route earns the name Broken Bridge Trail.

Accessed from the parking lot off Old Ingomar Road or from the Koto Buki Trail Purple/Black Dot Blaze, look for solid purple blazes. The trail begins by climbing towards Ridge Road (approx. 200 ft) before making a sharp right turn at the intersection with the Koto Buki Trail, just before the road.

From here, the trail descends all the way to the end, where it once again connects with the Koto Buki Trail, at the edge of the woods. Along the way, you'll follow the fence line of the police academy.  

Also, many singletrack spurs shoot off of the trail and can be taken to extend the loop or exit the woods on Ingomar Road before the end of the trail.
Hunting is allowed in the fall, so use caution on the trails at that time.

This is the only trail advertised in Highland Park. A sign off Reservoir Drive marks the start of the trail, which passes above the Pittsburgh Zoo. In summer, you can hear the howling monkeys near the end of the trail, which is also the only "climb" along the trail.

The end of the trail dumps you onto what appears to be an old road way, now covered over by grass.

This trail has several road crossings along Ridge Road, but a lesser used road and within the park limits, making them safer as people tend to drive a bit slower (fingers crossed).

This trail connects the pool and golf course, opening the door for the Golf Course Trail (Orange Blaze) and Parish Hill Loop (Green Blaze).
Gravel doubletrack climb from White Deer Pike parking area to Zimmerman Road and Pine Flat Road, past the Dynamite Shack on the right.

This is a very easy and short loop that is on the grounds of Gobbler's Knob where the Groundhog's Day ceremony is held every year.  It begins and ends next to the visitor center/museum.  It is a flat and wide trail that leads through a wooded area and is lined by informational displays, metal art installations, and picnic tables.  Once it curves around, the stage area is on the left.  It then continues back through the parking lot to the trailhead.

Starting at the parking area, follow the trail to Thompson Rd and turn right.  Walk down this road until you get to the turn to Lesher.  If you want to cut the hike short, you can follow Lesher to the end of this trail.

At the turn, head straight down the trail that seems to go straight when the road turns left.  This will take you down to the Skippack Creek.  While the trail might be poorly marked, if you follow the creek you'll eventually end up at an area to turn left.  If you miss this, you'll get to the bridge.  If you cross the bridge you'll get onto the Skippack Loop Trail.

Heading left, you'll go uphill to Lesher Rd. to the point where it becomes abandoned.  From here I would turn around if just doing this trail, or head down to the end of Lesher to cross the road.

If you are feeling brave, head left to the end of this trail.  There is a very deep stream crossing in which you'll either get completely soaked or get stabbed by thorns finding a way around.

This trail does not have a name.  To the West of PA Turnpike, this trail is outside of Valley Forge Park and is a paved single path.  The transition area under the Turnpike bridge is poorly maintained, muddy, and highly eroded.  To the East of the turnpike bridge (NPS Boundary), the trail is approximately 1 vehicle width mowed path through grassy fields. The trail follows Valley Creek across from Lafayette's Quarters.  

Just south of the Knox Farm, the trail crosses Valley Creek.  This crossing is designed for horses, at low water it is passable by bike, and when flow is low enough, it could probably be done on foot (although there is a foot bridge just a little farther ahead on Knox Trail).  Once on the East side of Valley Creek, the trail backtracks a little upstream to an abandoned forge before turning East across a field heading towards the "Airplane Field" (AKA "Archery Field").  This field hosts a model radio controlled airplane club.  In 1969, Valley Forge park hosted the first World Archery Championships held outside of Europe.  Perhaps this explains the "Archery Field" name.

This hike starts off of a paved campsite road and follows the gravel access road along the power lines. The trail is relatively flat in the beginning, and requires a small stream crossing. 

Towards the end, the rocks uphill are large and loose. At the top, there is a view. A connection to the Plantation Trail and Fireline Trail is accessible via this trail.

This trail, like so many in Western PA, has a climb in it that makes it ideal for starting a hike, but not so much when finishing.  

It starts by the Pool, park at the ballfield, and uses a very brief section of the Rachel Carson Trail to lead you into the woods. It wraps around the pool, over Babcock Blvd (be careful) and finally passes over the ALL Purple Blaze before leading to the Purple/Black Dot Blaze, or the Koto Buki Trail. Either purple blazed trail will lead you to the same place.

The trail connects between the north and south sides of the lake. It is both doubletrack and fire road. A suspension bridge at the midway point of the trail is unique as it has a lot of bounce and kayaks often pass underneath.

The southern trailhead starts by crossing Squaw Run by way of stepping stones before climbing a staircase.  

The trail winds along the hillside with a few vantage points of the Zen's Trail and Squaw Run below. The trail has a few sections with roots, but, in general, it is a very nice trail.
Land Manager:  Cumberland County

This is the Ho-Ya-Neh Trail but at the trailhead there is also a sign for the Bear Wallow Trail, which heads to the southeast to the Rock Oak Trail.  

The trail takes a right shortly after it starts and stays on top of the hill. If you go straight, on the wide path, you'll be on the Ho-Ya-Neh Trail. 

You'll start down a wide logging-like road made of dirt and something like natural oversized gravel, and it's all downhill. It can get steep in spots and may have some ruts.

This fire road provides access to many trails in the southern section of the park, and is a quick access when wanting to reach the top of the pool hill. Also, the southern terminus dumps you onto Wildwood Road via an Allegheny County maintenance building.
This is described as a drivable trail on the DCNR Michaux Map. When traveled in mid-summer, the trail was level and easy to follow. The only issue was the tall weeds growing in the sunny areas.

The trailheads are located at both parking lots within the park. The trail is a fine crushed gravel, smooth, and without any significant climbs. It is heavily traveled by hikers, dogs (off leash), and horses.

This is a nice loop that starts at the archery practice area. It can connect to Lost Boy - White Blaze Black Dot trail or White Blaze. It starts out as doubletrack until it crosses the White Blaze where it becomes singletrack. 

Use caution as this trail is frequented by more hikers and dog walkers than most of the other trails.

This portion of the MST follows unmarked PA Route 26, on sidewalk and well past where sidewalk ends, eventually crossing through an industrial park.

Begin climbing a ridgeline while crossing through the industrial park where orange blazes begin. Watch carefully for blazes around Blue Triangle Hardwoods' active log loading yard. Continue on past a dirt Game Land parking area (drivers have to go through the log yard!) and climb more steeply, eventually passing through the Scully Squeeze rock formation. 

From there, continue on upwards, and make your way over large boulders. Meet the MST proper on the top of the ridge. The Blue Triangle-Scully Squeeze portion of the trail will become the main trail once the route is open to Everett's Tenley Path - see  hike-mst.org/index.php/guid… for updates.

While this route isn't the most scenic portion of the trail, it is the preferred way to make your way through urban Everett.

Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Bald Eagle State Forest

The trail is accessed from the Hartwood Acres Purple Loop near the mansion parking lot.  Starting south you'll follow the purple loop for a few hundred feet before jumping across the road/walking path and continuing the Orange Loop.

The trail is smooth with a dip into a valley and a climb back out but not terribly challenging.  You'll poke out of the woods for a brief period, and on a hot summer day it feels like jumping into and then out of a furnace.

Connected to the Orange Loop is the White Loop.

The Beaver Dam Path trailhead is found among spruce trees along the aptly named Spruce Run. The trail runs steadily downhill for nearly two thirds of its length before running head on into Bog Run. This is a tricky spot, as the natural flow of the trail would have hikers continue straight; however, to continue on Beaver Dam Path, take the hard right. This final third of trail is steep and runs within a washout full of 1' diameter boulders. The trail ends at Trout Run.

The Green Loop is accessible from Hartwood Acres Red Loop and Hartwood Acres Yellow Loop, or the paved road/walk path, but there isn't a real trailhead from the path.

While the red loop circumnavigates the hill, the green loop takes you to the top and back down in just a mile of trail.  The trail is typical to Western PA.  It has some roots, mainly dirt, and after a rainfall can become slightly slick and hard to scramble in one area in particular.

This trail begins as a gentle singletrack, which can be muddy at times, just north of the warming hut at a signed entrance. The middle section shares its doubletrack alignment, and the single small hill, with Interstate Trail.  Shortly beyond the top of the hill, it branches off to the left on a wide singletrack that crosses Bill Albert's Trail and connects to Lippo's Loop Trail. This section is smooth graded for groomed cross country skiing, but is a good introduction to hiking in the woods.

The warming hut is open 24/7 to provide shelter from inclement weather, including a wood burning stove for heat.  Pit toilets are adjacent.  No overnight camping.

This trail can be accessed at the fire road or ball fields at the North Park Pools. The trail climbs the entire way, passing over rocky soil with roots sticking out. The trail is easy to follow, and is blazed with white and yellow dots.

The Transition Trail is just a simple trail on the edge of a field that connects to other trails that branch off into the woods. At just over a mile in length, this trail is a good option to connect with other trails in the park for a longer hike.

The Black Oak Savanna Trail is a very easy, flat field trail used to connect to other trails at the park.

From the southern MST junction, this is a brief singletrack to a gated logging road.

Hikers will pass a gate, cross Babb Creek on a road bridge, and begin following the narrow dirt South Elk Run Road. There is a three car pull off on South Elk Run Rd, about 100 yards north of Arnot Road. Do not park on Arnot Road - there is no shoulder, and it is a narrow road with tight curves and an angry landowner.

Rejoin the MST (here yellow blazed) at Hickory Ridge Rd intersection.
This partial loop drops below Pool Boy and ultimately leads you to Alameda Park Road and the eventual road crossing onto Skinny Girls.

Colt Trail follows red blazes and runs adjacent to the Short N Sweet Trail (510) which follows the yellow blazes. There is a short, shared climbing section with both red and yellow blazes. 

The Colt Trail is mostly an old hunting access road converted to doubletrack. It's mostly wide and flat without a lot of obstacles or climbing. 

This is a good trail to use as an easy warm-up loop, beginner trail, or easy bail out.
This trail is accessed from the Hartwood Acres Orange Loop and does a short mile long hill climb.  It's smooth dirt singletrack lacking much in the way of rock, roots, or obstacles.

Old Barbours Road is just a dirt road used to access some great trails such as the Brushy Ridge Trail. While not particularly exciting on its own, Old Barbours Road can be used as an easy connector to the other trails in the area.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Tiadaghton State Forest
This is State Lands Game property, hunting is allowed.
Land Manager:  PA DNR - Jacobsburg Environmental Education Center
Whitetail Crossing is located on the edge of a field with a short section ending in woods connecting to other trails that lead to the lake.

This doubletrack trail was originally constructed to provide snowmobile access to the ski lodge from Laurel Summit Road.

It begins at Laurel Summit Road, just south of the main parking area and extends to the ski area access road beside the Bureau of Forestry maintenance building. This trail provides access to Lippos Loop and to an unnamed singletrack trail that extends past the ski lodge.

Not officially named or signed.

Trail access is from the main road or from the Waterfall Trail. 

Starting from the east end, the trail picks up after Waterfall Trail and follows along an elevation contour around the hollow. The trail pulls away from the hillside before crossing Muddy Run. Then it returns to more hillside trail, wrapping up at the main road or Bog Run. 

The hillside sections are wide singletrack, unlike Bog Run. There are roots to be aware of, but ultimately this is a smooth trail.

The trail is a point-to-point U-shaped section with access from the Spring Hollow Trail at the 4-way intersection with Upper Fields (north end) or from Upper Fields in the south end. The trail is a singletrack section with lots of roots. The trail passes by an old oil well and motor, tucked beneath a rickety shed. Meadowview is also the only access to the Pine Hollow Trail.

For those of you that want to explore a little more, this trail can start at the top of Bower Fields Trails. There are a few other odd logging roads in this area, so be mindful of that.  

This trail will take you from Bower to Mountain Road, all within WMWA. It starts out with a rolling uphill and then is fairly flat, but with roots and a few downed logs until you get to the pavement.

This connector can be easily seen off both the Red Trail in Redd Park and off the Double Horseshoe trail in Middle Run. You head through a church parking lot and synagogue parking lot and need to cross Possum Park Rd.  

Be careful as cars come up over the hill quickly and fast on this road. These churches are private property so be respectful as they have tolerated travel using this path without incident.

Trail access is available from the Gravel Path (shown above) or the Beaver Dam Path. Access is also available using the Chestnut Path after it crosses the main road.

The trail itself is gently rolling following closely with an elevation grade along a hillside. The trail is narrow with roots and rocks, much like most of the trails in the park system. Hikers will cross several alternate trails, namely Pipeline Pass and Swamp Hill before ending at Beaver Dam Path.
Falcon has a short punchy climb to reach the top of the hill and then it pitches back down a steep chute into a series of turns.

If you park in Lot #5 and head down the road toward the lake, you'll eventually arrive at the out flow of South Branch  Little Aughwick Creek. Turn to the right and follow the trail around the lake on your left.

Starting from the intersection with Spring Hollow Trail just behind the ASWP building, the trail runs through woods along a hillside, climbing slowly to a major 4-way intersection with Meadowview Trail and Spring Hollow Trail.

This mostly flat trail takes you from one end of the parking lot to the other, never getting more than 100 feet away from Pool Drive. The upper section is a remake of an original park trail, with the limestone creek crossing being greatly improved!

This is a yellow-blazed gravel road bypass around a portion of MST Section 18 (and the Wimbrough Campsite) that's closed Oct 15-Jan 15 during big game hunting seasons. The bypass continues south to Miller Hill Road (further than shown) as there is additional off road trail of MST Section 18 not shown on this map.

Dirt road (gated) descent from Locust Camp Road parking. There's a small access point, with space for a few cars. Turning onto Locust Trail will take you to Bill Alberts Trail, the unnamed ski area trail or on to the Laurel Mountain Ski slopes.  

The road continues downhill beyond Locust Trail to a point further down the ski slopes.  Be alert for the intersection if you dont want a bigger climb back out.

Similar to the other segments in this area, this singletrack trail is carved along the hillside, separate from the Green Lane Park Red Trail route. This area is connected by a path at the top of the hill. Expect roots and some switchback sections, which are all manageable. 

These are also used as horse trails, but much of these trails are through narrow trees. Connects to the Green Lane Park Loop via the Red Trail.

From Fulton Run Road, this doubletrack travels up a fairly steep hill that runs under power lines and then cuts into the woods ending at the College Lodge Parcourse after a second climb. The terrain is a bit rocky with some roots, but it is not difficult. The doubletrack provides easy travel in either direction. This trail connects with Spring, Friends, Bronson, and Fulton.

Located near the end of Sunnyside Road, this trail heads away from the reservoir and toward Mountain Road on the map. That section of Mountain Rd is private and there is a cable across it marked with a posted sign. Taking the right (as the trail is mapped) will take you back to Sunnyside Road. There is a left turn shortly after that connects to Shuler Road. Enjoy connecting all of these small roads into a fun, shaded adventure.
Usually traveled uphill to get to Eagle Rock from the west side. Starts steeper in the beginning but then levels off.
A grassy singletrack climb or descent depending on direction.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Tiadaghton State Forest

Jump right into the woods when headed to Sassafras XX from the parking lot on Coopers Gap Road instead of grinding up Flat Road. Take the Shittaka Trail entrance next to the parking lot, headed southwest. After less than a mile of moderate climbing, you'll come to an intersection. Turn left onto Indian Trail.  About 0.4 miles later you'll come out on Flat Road.

This trail continues the drop down the hillside from the pool towards the lower park road and the park office. It, like the trails above it, Swam Pass and Pool Boy, is rolling, mostly straight, and pretty much flat (except for the switchbacks!).
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest
From the McKenna Trail connects back to Firetower Road.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Tiadaghton State Forest
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest
Land Manager:  PA DCNR - French Creek
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest

Access to this trail can be found at the intersection of Nichol Road and Pioneer Camp Road or off Pinto Loop Trail.  

From Nichol Road, the trail heads downhill and is cut into the slope. Wide enough for horses to traverse, the trail can become soggy and is pitted with horse tracks.

You'll pass Camp Trail on the left before coming to a Y in the trail. Take the right, heading uphill at a pair of wood log steps. The left connects with Heritage Trail.
Mud and downed trees after first boat launch.
This is just a dirt/gravel road that is best used to access the Bluedot Switchback, Red Run Trail (Downhill) and Red Run Trail (Uphill), which make up most of the trails of the Little Bear area.

trail_name: Montour Trail: Peter's Creek Road to North State Street
description:
This section of the Montour Trail is a level section heading into Clairton from Route 51. Parking is available at the park n' Ride lot immediately before the trailhead on Peters Creek Road. The trail runs along Peters Creek Road before the road ends and the trail enters denser woods and winds along the creek at the base of a hill.  

When in Clairton, hikers can access McKeesport and the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP) trail following roadways. See Montour Trail for more details.
Appalachian Trail (AT)
This path encompasses Squaw Valley Park, and acts as an entry point to the Salamander Trail and Old Squaw Trail. The trail is a cinder path used by walkers, those with dogs, and runners.

Access to this trail is from Nichol Road, at either end, or from Forest Trail midway.

The trail is doubletrack, shared with horseback riding, making it rutted in muddy sections. The final turn at the northern end is a sharp left onto a singletrack section before coming back to Nichol Road.

The trail is located just off the upper parking lot. Hiking south, the trail bridges the parking lot with the Muddy Run Trail, and eventually the longer Chestnut Path and Bog Run trails.

In the beginning, the trail dips to a small pond with wooden deck and benches. The trail is smooth with no real obstacles. It T's into Muddy Run. A right at the intersection goes back to the main road, and left heads towards Chestnut Path and the base of the hill at Cabin Hollow.

Used primarily as a connector between the Orange Loop and Koto Buki Trail (Purple/Black Dot Blaze), the trail that parallels Kummer Road. The trail travels at a steady slope, and typically throughout the year has pockets of ground water that can get sloppy at times.

This trail is mainly used as a way to connect a parking lot on the outskirts of Raccoon Creek State Park and the main Appaloosa Trail. The trail is heavily traveled by horseback; therefore, this trail does have heavy rutting from horses. While this route is an option for adding some mileage to your route, there are many more enjoyable trails within the park.

The trail can be accessed from the southern terminus of Waterthrush Way or from Fern Hollow Road at the park maintenance building; the trail starts at the building road entrance.  

The trail is rugged with plenty of river rock and several very short, but steepish climbs. Hikers will cross over several seasonal streams with river rock beds.

The trail starts roughly from the upper parking lot. At the far end of the lot is a fire road to the end of the park property.  Take a right at the end of the road to head back toward the park. Note, just before the end of the road is an intersection with the Gravel Path on the left, and an unmarked trail leading to the Butterfly Fields.

The Bridle Path is a tricky trail starting with a descent before a short climb and the final short descent to Waterthrush Way.  While considered separate trails, they are alike in trail surface, which is a mishmash of old concrete and loose stone.  Moreover, soil and vegetation has begun to grow in areas. This has left both trails in an odd situation where hikers will have to deal with uneven and constantly changing surfaces.  

The Bridle Path technically ends at a fork with Waterthrush Way to the left and the Laurel Trail to the right, which loops back to the Bridle Path.
This trail is a grass doubletrack that starts from the pond pavilion and runs south to Upper Fields Trail.

What makes this trail slightly challenging is the trail surface, a mishmash of old concrete, loose stone, dirt and grass.  The trail picks up at the end of the Bridle Path and descends the park hill to Cabin Hollow Trail.
A connecting trail between Panhandle Trail and Montour Trail.  Montour Trail passes over Panhandle Trail via an old trussed bridge.

The trail bridges Cabin Hollow Trail and Waterfall Trail. From the start, the trail descends the hillside quickly before leveling out to a slight downhill grade. The trail does provide some vantage points of the hollow floor as you descend.

The trail is a semi-loop, running along the hillside. The trail is accessed from the Bridle Path at either end, and also connects with the Waterfall Trail. The view of the valley floor is mostly hidden, but some thinner areas of underbrush allow for a brief view down the hillside.

There are not many rocks on the trail, although there are plenty of roots to make up for it.
Land Manager:  PA DCNR -  Tioga State Forest

There are some stairs between Braddock and Tranquil Trail and a 13% climb to get to the Clayton Loop. But you'll be rewarded for your effort with a great view! The trail isn't very long, so the tough climb is more rewarding than punishing, especially once you reach the top.

Land Manager:  PA DCNR - Tyler State Park

This short trail is perfect for visitors who are seeking a bit more adventure. The park is tranquil, featuring pavilions and picnic locations. For your after lunch hike, head out on this short, but perfectly shady trail. Along the way, you'll enjoy meandering past Core Creek, which burbles past as you hike. 

Once you complete this short loop, you can extend your outing by continuing on to the main Core Creek Loop, or you can head back to your picnic spot for a rest.
