This is a fairly long trail with steep hills. It winds through natural forests descending into ravines across two streams. The trail joins three picnic areas, any of which may be used as a starting point. This trail also follows a short section of Trail 1.

The Bailly Cemetery Trail, along with the Bailly Homestead / Chellberg Farm Trail and Little Calumet River / Mnok Prairie Trail, reveal the rich natural diversity that has drawn people to this area for over 10,000 years. Hike through a forest dominated by maple, beech, basswood, and oak trees. Follow a stretch of the Little Calumet River, once a critical transportation route for early regional travelers. Explore the recently restored Mnok Prairie for a glimmer of the vast stretches of pre-settlement grasslands.

Visit the Bailly Homestead and Chellberg Farm to glimpse how families lived and farmed in Northwest Indiana. 

The Bailly Homestead, a National Historic Landmark (1962), was the home of Honore Gratien Joseph Bailly de Messein (1774 - 1835). Bailly played a role in the development of the Calumet Region of northern Indiana. He was an independent trader in the extensive fur-trading network that spread from Montreal to Louisiana, and ultimately to Europe. Joseph Bailly was one of the earliest settlers in northern Indiana. In 1822, Bailly set up his fur trading post at the crossroads of several important trails. The Bailly Homestead complex is the last remaining site of its nature in the Calumet Region.

In the 1870s, Swedish immigrants Anders and Johanna "Kjellberg" bought 80 acres to establish a modest family farm. They were the first of three generations of the Chellberg Family to make their living here. In the 1930s, the Chellbergs started to tap the many maple trees on their property for the production of maple syrup.

The Annual Maple Sugar Time event in early March features the evolution of "maple sugaring" in Northwest Indiana from an early American Indian method, to the pioneer method of boiling sap in open iron kettles, to the relatively modern commercial method of producing syrup. Indiana Dunes National Park is the only National Park Service location that makes maple syrup.

Taylor Ridge Trail #9 is a moderately trafficked lollipop trail located near Nashville, Indiana that has beautiful wildflowers and is rated as moderate. The trail can be accessed year round, and it has some steep inclines and declines.

Starting off on its namesake ridge, the trail traverses gentle grades through the woods to the end of the ridgeline, at which point it dives sharply into the drainage below. From here, the trail follows the gentle upslope of the drainage through pristine forests before climbing back up the ridgeline to its end. From its end, take a right to follow a stretch of trail from earlier back to the trailhead and the Taylor Ridge Campground.
Land Manager:  Indiana State Parks

This rail trail links several cities and other rail trails together. The western trailhead is in downtown Hobart and connects to the Oak Savannah Trail. The eastern end of the trail is in Porter and connects to the Porter Brickyard Trail. There are parking lots at each end and several parking lots along the trail.

This trail starts at the junction with Tecumseh Trail, Lake Trail, and High King Trail. From here, the Scarce O'Fat Trail heads west-northwest ascending a ridgeline through Southern Indiana hardwood forest. This trail is adequately blazed, however, numerous intersections with horse trails and logging/fire roads necessitate paying attention. The final third coincides with a doubletrack forest road.
There is a porta-potty on the upper point on the trail.

From the fire tower, head east and the trail soon crosses over the gravel road where the trail gradually descends into a valley. The trail has some water erosion, but is wide enough to hike alongside. A few creek crossings down in the valley can be challenging after a heavy rain. The trail occasionally meanders part ways up the side of the hill and affords some nice elevated views of the creek below. Eventually the trail rises up and weaves through an old pine grove before meeting with the Foxy Hollow Trail about 1 mile from the trailhead. Continuing south on the fire tower trail, you'll cross another gravel road, and then arrive at another fork in the trail in about 1.3 miles. The fork to the right (southwest) will lead you to the campground. The fork to the left (southeast) continues down into another valley where the trail meets the Twin Lakes Trail. Just before meeting the Twin Lakes Trail is a wide, shallow creek crossing that may lead to wet feet if unable to find enough stepping stones.

The trail is well marked with red rectangular blazes.

This is one of the longest trails in Whitewater Memorial State Park and begins at the parking area near the Hornbeam Nature Preserve. From the parking lot, follow the signs into the trees. The first part of the trail includes a half mile loop via the Lakeshore Trail Alternate. You can choose to go left or right since both directions will eventually take you to the longer portion of the trail that follows the edge of the lake. 

Throughout this trail, you'll be hiking through Indiana woodlands with some hills and valleys that will take you near the water's edge for most of the trail. Shortly after the loop, there is a very short segment that will take you down to the water's edge. This is a great spot for a picture or just to watch the activity on the lake. As you continue from here, you'll be able to see various waterfowl. Plus, be on the lookout for small turtles and frogs sunning near the shore.

As you approach the end of the trail, you'll come to a wooden staircase that takes you down to the observation deck at the end of the trail. Depending on the time of year, you'll be able to see some views of the lake, but be advised the observation deck is at lake level but not actually on the lake. It is surrounded by trees, so your view may be blocked during the warmer seasons. While here, take some time to catch your breath and keep an eye and ear out for the various species of birds found in this area. From here, it's time to turn around and head back to the parking area. I personally like trails like this as you get to see the whole trail from both perspectives, coming and going.

This trail is great if you just want to get away for a few miles of hiking in a forest of dense trees. There is a variety of wildlife within the park, and the trails are well defined. There are many connector trails here, so utilize them if you feel like extending your hike.

Starting from its junction with Trail 2, this trail heads northwest along the banks of Eagle Creek to pass numerous pleasant views.
Can be tricky to exit during rush hour.

This trail begins like all others at the main trailhead. It then quickly departs the Yellow Blaze Trail and White Blaze Trail to head to the cave on a soft, leafy tread. This moderate trail is well marked with RED blazes and does not loop. Note that those going to the cave should obtain permission from the ranger staff at Camp Stem Girl Scout Camp before embarking.
Gate fee at park entrance.

Wandering around the tall open fields of natural Indiana grass on the high ground of the property, this trail is ideal for everyone. Starting and ending on Trail 9, this pleasant track is primarily flat and allows you to worry less about the trail and more about enjoying your beautiful surroundings.
Land Manager:  Indiana DNR - Clifty Falls State Park

The North Gate Trail is a nice start and end to your hike in the park. This gentle uphill climbs from the parking area to a junction with the North Tower Trail. Hikers also have the option to connect to the Pine Loop Trail near the beginning of North Gate which is a great option if you are looking to add some additional mileage or variety to your hike.
Land Manager:  DNR- Chain O Lakes State Park

A mostly singletrack trail that takes hikers around the back side of the lake. The trail starts and ends with a little fire lane section, but has some tight singletrack in the middle. A few tough climbs help keep it interesting.

This loop trail consists of a gravel, grass, and dirt footpath. There are two distinct sections of the trail. The first two miles are easy, the last mile is intermediate. The first 1.25 miles hike through open prairie and crosses a small creek overlooking a marshy floodplain. The trail then follows a bluff above the massive Wabash River. 

About 1.25 miles in, the trail becomes more wooded while following the Tippecanoe River, but remains mostly flat. There are a couple more creek crossings. Around 2 miles in, the trail becomes much more wooded and hilly. 

The remainder of the trail runs along a hillside with a few small inclines, a few staircases, and a couple creek crossings. The trail ends by the fishing pond.

Starting from the Lake Trail  (Trail 1) the east branch of the Firetower trail slowly climbs a medium sized hill (locally speaking), with a series of wooden stairs on the steeper part.

Once at the top of the hill, you may climb to the top of the fire tower at your own risk for some good views of the surrounding area.

The western branch of the Firetower trail returns you back to the Lake Trail (Trail 1) down a slightly more gradual slope that is covered in gravel with occasional steps.
Park entrance has a fee—take cash or cards.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Turkey Run State Park
Parking for three cars comfortably, five cars in a pinch.

This lollipop loop is the easiest in the park. If you're looking for a very short hike, take a left shortly after you begin Shadow Run to head down this trail. It's not technical and there are no big climbs like on Shadow Run.  You can go either direction around the loop at the end and return to the trailhead or if you're more adventurous, you can try the rest of Shadow Run next.

At the tip of the lollipop loop, Creekside branches off.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - McCormick's Creek State Park
Fairly easy trail along creek through woods past a fishing pier and a few bridges. Connects to the Pond Loop Trail.

There are two ways to reach Center Loop.  The easiest would be to follow Creekside Trail.  Alternatively, you could reach this loop by following the more difficult Cliffside trail.  Hike it in either direction as a lollipop loop to head back to the trailhead, or to add distance onto a larger loop of the trail system and link to Grandview Loop.

Look for some rocks and a bit more climbing as this trail goes higher on the bluffs.

Comment Type:

Trail 2 is a short trail just to the west of the town of Maumee. It is used to connect the roads N. County Road 1190 W. and N. County Road 1200 W. with Hickory Ridge Trail 18.

Trail 2 is often used by by those who wish to connect the Nebo Ridge Trail with the Hickory Ridge trail system.

There are two trail loops in the Crooked Lake Nature Preserve and a third, connected loop in the Ralph Gates Addition. The preserve contains over 0.5 mile of undeveloped shoreline on one of Indiana's cleanest and deepest lakes. Forested slopes are dominated by beech and sugar maple associated with green ash, shagbark hickory, red oak, sassafras and white oak. 

The understory consists of sugar maple, ironwood, green ash, beech, and flowering dogwood. There are wetland habitats including marshes and calcareous seeps along the shore, and an island in the lake itself. Parking is available on the Noble/Whitley county line road (600S/700N). The trail is also accessible from the end of W Northshore drive on Crooked Lake.
The trail starts out with a significant ascent, 825 ft. of elevation gain over the first 0.25 miles with about a 9.5% grade. It then levels out for a nice, smooth hike.

"The limestone shoreline around the point at Allen's Creek is so dense with fossils that it's hard to find 'plain' rock! The fossil beds are filled with crinoids and corals, interspersed with geodes – remnants of the shallow sea that once covered Indiana." - DNR Interpretive Services of the Paynetown Activity Center

The trail itself is an old gravel road. There are several optional spurs to explore. Short plants flourish along the road, so beware of ticks along its length. If it has been raining a lot, this might affect your enjoyment of the shore.

"Monroe Lake Trail — Our trails are built and maintained for the education and enjoyment of our visitors. Please assist in preserving the natural beauty of the area by observing the following rules and regulations:
• Always stay on the trail.
• Do not litter. Pack out any trash.
• All pets must be on a leash at all times.
• No collecting is allowed except for mushrooms, berries and nuts. [Do not take the nice fossils!]
• Foot traffic only. No bicycles or motorized vehicles allowed.
• Do not damage or destroy any natural or man-made items."

This trail is located in Cicero, just north of Noblesville off of 37. The Southern Loop Trail is a little over 3 miles long, and hikers can easily piece together longer outings with the different loops and through trails that is connects with. There is a nice historic railroad bridge on the White River Campground Connector that takes you over to a the White River Campground with a restroom and water. 

This is located on old Native American land so there are some pretty cool displays/exhibits at the front of the park. Make sure to bring water with you if planning on doing the full north and south loops. There is not a lot of shade and no water fountains along the trail.
This is a paved asphalt path through Happy Hollow, good for a short hike out and back.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Brown County State Park

From the Camp Glenn Trailhead off Shafter Road, enter the trail at the western edge of the parking lot.  Follow the trail counter-clockwise, so keep right at the first intersection. Keep left at the second intersection with the Lawrence Creek Trail and then keep right to return to the parking lot.

This trail is a wide, smooth singletrack trail through mostly open hardwood forest. Watch for poison ivy and stinging nettles growing alongside the trail in the warm months. There are some mild obstacles here that will keep beginners on their toes.  

There is a small rocky section with an alternate route, and there are a few rocks alongside the trail.

Park at the Nature Center. Trail 7 connects the Nature Center to the beach and avoids the tallest of the dunes. Trail 7 can be used in conjunction with Trail 8 - 3 Dunes Challenge if you want to do only some of the tall dunes.

The Indiana Dunes State Park was established in 1925 and contains 2,182 acres of land. The park is home to the tallest sand dunes in the area that approach 200 feet in height. The park contains a diverse range of beach, forest, and wetland habitats. As a result, this is an incredible spot for birding. There are three miles of pristine beaches along the Lake Michigan shoreline. 

Visit the park's website for information on programs, camping, and other activities.

This trail starts at North Meridian Street, but most will use it as a branch off the Monon Trail, where it departs immediately after crossing Fall Creek. There is a short leg that continues east, but the length of the trail goes west following Fall Creek until reaching Fort Benjamin Harris State Park. 

This is a paved urban trail running through a greenway as it cuts through the city of Indianapolis. The trail is great for running, hiking, and biking, though there are a few places which can be muddy after a rain. "Fort Ben" as it's locally known is a great reward at the end of the 10-mile trek. 

Fort Benjamin has its own trail system and is an Indiana State Park. There is no attendant at the Fall Creek entrance, but a pass is required to visit the park. A day pass or yearly state park pass can be obtained at the main gate of the park which is a short ways from the Fall Creek entrance.

The West Beach Trail (Loop 2) is an easy 1.4-mile hike through an area that was sand mined in the 1920s. The footing is mainly loose sand. This area is being restored as an oak savanna and is a great place to see prickly pear cactus. Birders will enjoy looking for water birds on Long Lake from the viewing platform.

The trail is not accessible to wheelchairs. However, there is a paved road from the parking lot to the bathhouse that offers views of Lake Michigan that is accessible to wheelchairs. The main parking lot has spots for 596 cars and is open year round. 

There are restroom facilities and potable water available year round in the West Beach Contact Station. Seasonal showers, lockers and a beach (with lifeguards) are available in the summer.

There are covered picnic shelters near the West Beach parking lot. First come, first served. No advance reservations. Wheelchair accessible. Alcohol is not permitted anywhere at West Beach. Cooking fires at the picnic shelters are permitted in the provided grills or an approved carry-in grill. An approved grill is a noncombustible container with an enclosed bottom and enclosed sides with a minimum depth of 2 inches. Charcoal must be cooled and safely disposed of in a noncombustible container or removed from the area.

Indiana Dunes National Park (formerly national lakeshore) was established to preserve portions of the Indiana Dunes and other areas of scenic, scientific, historic and recreational value. Up to two million annual visitors enjoy the park's 15,000 acres of wetlands, prairies, sand dunes, oak savannas, forests, and historic sites. The park's 15 miles of beaches hug the southern shore of Lake Michigan from Gary, IN, to Michigan City, IN. For more information, visit  nps.gov/indu or  facebook.com/IndianaDunesNPS.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Brown County State Park

This is a multi-use trail, allowing backpacking, mountain biking, and snowmobiles.

There is a fee to enter the park, and there is a fee to use a backcountry campsite also. Visit the Interpretive Center at the trailhead, where there is a patch available for the hike. You'll need waterproof footgear and sun screen; hiking through the grass in the morning will get your feet wet from the dew, and hiking through the fields and open will have full sun exposure.

The White Blaze Trail was 8 years in the making, and boy is it worth it! Along the trail, you're bound to see wildlife, old graves, a scenic woodland lake, a rope bridge, multiple overlooks of the Ohio River, and last, but not least, an underground waterfall!

Allow an afternoon to complete this trail, as anything less might leave you finishing in the dark.

Starting at the parking area, follow the trail as it shares a joint singletrack with the Yellow Blaze Trail before peeling off to the right at a fork. Once on its own soft-and-leafy singletrack, the White Blaze Trail takes you on an almost comprehensive tour of the area, visiting great viewpoints and points of interest throughout the camp.

If you don't think you'll be able to finish the entire loop, there is a bailout point at the junction with the Green Blaze Trail. Simply follow the Green Blaze Trail until it dead ends into the parking area.
There are public restrooms and vending at Howell Park. There are no amenities in the wetlands.

At the north end, the trail starts at the Cowles Bog South Access (Greenbelt Trail) parking lot located at U.S. Highway 20 and Mineral Springs Road. There is a porta-potty, but no potable water source. This is also the western end of the Calumet Bike Trail which runs east for 9.5 miles to Michigan City.

From the north parking lot, the trail heads south and immediately crosses over U.S. Highway 12 using a pedestrian overpass. The next section features winding trail through the national lakeshore. The trail picks up Howe Road and travels south to U.S. Highway 20, crossing the highway using a pedestrian overpass.

The rest of the trail to the south uses a mixture of sidewalks, dedicated paths and city streets to the southern trailhead. The Prairie Duneland Trail, which runs from Chesterton to Hobart, is also located here. There is a parking lot with ample parking.

The Dunes Kankakee Trail is an ambitious trail project that, if and when completed, will run the entire length of Porter County. It will connect the  Indiana Dunes National Park and Indiana Dunes State Park at the north end to the Kankakee River at the south end. It would tie into the coast-to-coast American Discovery Trail at its southern terminus.

As of 2016, the trail is only 1.8 miles long and stretches from the State Park entrance gates to the Indiana Dunes Visitor Center. The trail also connects to the Calumet Bike Trail and the Dunes Park South Shore Railroad train station.

This rail trail uses the roadbed of a former Indiana Harbor Belt Railroad line. The roundtrip distance is 4.7 miles. It is flat and mostly free of obstacles, which make it especially easy to navigate. The trail is not accessible to wheelchairs. There are no restrooms or potable water sources available, so come prepared.

There is a separate entrance to the parking lot off of County Line Road just north of the main West Beach entrance. There is no access fee for this parking lot.

Indiana Dunes National Park (formerly national lakeshore) was established to preserve portions of the Indiana Dunes and other areas of scenic, scientific, historic and recreational value. Up to two million annual visitors enjoy the park's 15,000 acres of wetlands, prairies, sand dunes, oak savannas, forests, and historic sites. The park's 15 miles of beaches hug the southern shore of Lake Michigan from Gary, IN, to Michigan City, IN. For more information, visit  nps.gov/indu or  facebook.com/IndianaDunesNPS.

The trail begins at the Oriole Trail East/West Parking Area and wanders into the woods. After crossing SR-66 the trail eventually links up to a logging access road where past and current logging is occuring. The trail follows the logging road for the better part of 3 miles (if hiking counter-clockwise). Once off the roadway you'll pass through some logged areas before entering the woods; from this point on, the trail is phenomenal. You'll pass through a creek valley that is almost surreal before gaining elevation to a spot above the Little Blue River that provides wonderful vistas during the winter months.

This trail is located in Cicero, just north of Noblesville off of 37. The Northern Loop Trail is just over two-miles long and loops around a natural prairie grassland. This loop was partially under water when we went, so we had to turn around at the northwestern side of the loop, but normally you can continue to to connect to the Southern Trail Loop or loop back to your starting point to complete the full trail.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Lincoln State Park

This route ends up being a nice shorter trail. The going is mostly on hard packed dirt with a few low spots that stay soft after wet weather. The trail is used for local cross country meets, as well as the occasional cycling race, so be aware of any closures.

This trail starts out easy enough with a downhill on gravel. Hang a left IMMEDIATELY after you cross the bridge and take the small trail up the hillside. Do not go straight—it is not the trail. After you take the left you are going to be going uphill through brush on a narrow trail with LOTS of ticks. I used a couple different big sprays, but nothing seemed to work for the ticks. Near the end of the trail it opens up a little but not much.
All visitors in the field must wear fluorescent orange hat or vest during allowed deer and turkey hunting seasons.  The seasons are shortened durations from the state-defined seasons.

This trail is shaped a bit like a lollipop, which means that a short way down the trail from the parking area is a fork. We went to the right to start our way around the loop. 

The first part of this trail goes through the woods and is more difficult than the other 3/4 of the trip. There are pretty views and it's only a moderate trail, not too strenuous, to the first waterfall (approx. 1/4 mile in). There are twp potential creek crossings depending on water level. The creek isn't too wide and we were able to cross in winter without getting wet (the second crossing had more water than the first). 

After about 1/2 to 3/4 of a mile you'll be out of the woods and on to the wide and mostly flat grass path through a fairly young pine grove. There is a short boardwalk through a small wetlands area around mile 1. To shorten the outing, you could cut across one of the connector paths to make a shorter loop. The paths and trail are well maintained (at least they were clear in the winter) and easy to follow. I highly recommend not missing the first part of the trail if you are at all interested in the views!

The Green Blaze Trail is a camp favorite that, while small in length, is big in trailside spectacles. Mainly, this trail leads to the camp's underground waterfall (a sub-surface expression of water that is viewable through a "skylight" in the ground above).

Starting at the Parking Area, the trail heads east through picturesque Indiana hardwoods on a leafy tread until reaching a junction with the White Blaze Trail. Make a right at the junction to continue on the Green Blaze Trail, climbing gently out of the woodlands for a brief moment to skirt the edge of a field. After diving back into the woodlands at the end of the field, the trail traverses the same woods from before, now heading downhill, for a short distance before popping out onto a doubletrack road. As quickly as the trail joins the road, it both dives back into the woods and increases in steepness drastically. Upon reaching the road for a second time, the trail offers great views of the lake and a great spot to enjoy some water or a snack.

When you're ready to continue, the trail makes a sharp left turn to climb gently along the banks of Big Run. With roughly half a mile of creekside trail (which is actually only running after heavy rains or flooding), you'll have plenty of time to enjoy its pleasant company. After rejoining the White Blaze Trail briefly, the end of the trail is met with its most interesting feature: the underground waterfall.

Cascading under the surface, this waterfall is only visible through a small opening in the ground that's partially covered by rocks and detritus. Further adding to its novelty is the lack of visible water anywhere else around it, and the large hills to its sides. For those that know a thing or two about groundwater, this can be an interesting spot to give a lesson to those uninitiated.

Once you've enjoyed the waterfall to your heart's content, you can either return the way you came, or you can jump onto the White Blaze Trail to extend your pleasant experience in these Indiana woodlands.

The Trail #9 loop begins at the Deer Run parking area and loops through hardwood forest, old farm fields, and crosses a bridle trail twice before ending back at the Deer Run area. This loop is fairly flat and relatively easy making for a nice hike in either direction.

This trail leads from the modern campground between wooded hills, descending to a small steam along the way. From there, the path meanders on an old country road next to a fast flowing brook, with some steep hills in certain places. Eventually, the trail returns to the modern campground entrance.

Though this is a relatively short trail, it leads from the youth tent campground into a ravine and gradually ascends into both wooded areas and grassy plateaus. This trail returns to the youth tent area, past one of the largest pecan trees in the state.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Prophetstown State Park
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation
A loop trail that begins between family cabins 6 and 14, loops through large native timber in McCormick’s Cove Nature Preserve and ends at the entrance to the Family Cabin Area.

The Hobart Woodland Trail is an extension off the Oak Savannah Trail. Park at the Robinson Lake parking lot on South Liverpool Road just north of East 53rd Avenue. Follow the Oak Savannah rail trail east for just under a half mile. Look for the the Hobart Woodland trailhead on the south side of the rail trail just before the woods start. There is a foot bridge. The packed dirt singletrack trail will head south following the wood line for a short distance before entering the woods. The trail makes its way to a scenic overlook of Lake George. There a small loop offering different views of the lake.

The Hobart Prairie Grove preserves several habitats including wetlands, prairie remnants, white oak flatlands, and a rare bur oak savanna. At about 300 acres in size, it contains 343 native plants and an abundance of wildlife. This area is also noteworthy because of a unique soil that is made up of at least 70 percent silt and clay with the smaller portions of sand. This type of soil is one of the reasons for the outstanding diversity of life here at Hobart Prairie Grove. This very special place was added to the National Park System as part of a 1992 expansion of Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore (now the Indiana Dunes National Park).

Starting at the Yellowwood Lake dam parking area, climb up to the top of High King Hill for some of the best views in Brown County and Yellowwood State Forest, especially in winter when leaves are off the trees. 

High King Trail is also part of the long distance Tecumseh Trail.
Park entrance is generally free during cold months but $7 for Indiana residents and $9 for others.

-Wear blaze orange during deer and turkey hunting seasons. 
-There is no potable water along the trail, so bring your own or be prepared to filter from several substantial creeks.  
-This is a multi-use trail.  
-Horses have the right-of-way, mountain bikes yield to foot-traffic. 
-Ticks are abundant during warm months so defend yourself accordingly.

trail_name: Knobstone Trail (KT): Delaney Park Loop, South

1.7-mile singletrack close to Purdue University nestled between the golf course and Cherry lane. There's a small parking area at the trailhead and/or about 200 yards away from a paved trail that runs from Purdue to West Lafayette.

The trail is generally clear as it's built for biking.  So there are few roots and rocks.  A few small hills provide a bit of work and the continuous winding keep your attention.  The south side of the trail can be muddy after rain.

This is a nice beginner trail or a quick hike at lunch time.
Cell service may be spotty.  There are no restrooms or facilities along this trail, and only one significant stream crossing.  Water may be hard to find in dry weather.

Starting at the Mounds Campground Shelterhouse, the trail travels parallel to Templeton Creek Road before turning right and heading into the woods. You'll soon cross a small, now broken footbridge built by Boy Scout Troop 40 of Liberty, IN. The trail remains mostly flat and heavily shaded for the next mile. You'll soon come across a peaceful pond on the left side of the trail.

Around a mile in, you'll pass cropland and a few small, grassy meadows. You may notice the strange evenly spread out mix of pine and deciduous trees along this trail, especially compared to the other trails around Brookville Lake. About 1.5 miles in, the trail will descend down towards the lake. You'll be able to catch glimpses of the lake in late fall, winter, and early spring.

The rest of the trail follows the side of Garr Hill running parallel to the lake and a small river. Eventually the trail descends and crosses the small river with an obnoxiously large concrete bridge. The remainder of the trail is flat and follows the river to the Garr Hill Boat Ramp and parking.

This smooth paved trail makes a loop around the lake, and is very well built. There is plenty to see and tons of waterfowl. The playgrounds are perfect for the kids, and lots of room to expend energy.
Portable toilets are currently available.
Restroom access at Bonwell Hill boat ramp parking area. Restroom closed in winter.

There are tons of thorns and stickers on this trail. There needs to be some serious maintenance done to improve this trail. Also, this trail is not heavily trafficked, and the path itself can become hard to find, especially when there are only a few faint white blazes to help guide your way, in addition to the occasional orange ribbon tied to a tree. Between miles 2 and 3 in particular is poorly marked.

This is a nice paved path that runs along along the Little Calumet River. As mapped, the path starts in Optimist Park. The path heads east, passing the junction with the Erie Lackawanna Trail almost immediately. At 0.2 miles the trail crosses Kennedy Ave.; please use caution crossing this busy road. The trail winds along the river and ends just east of the junction Oxbow Park Connector (also called Oxbow Park Trail, though this would be the most easterly junction).

trail_name: James P. Covell Nature Preserve Trail
description: The trail starts from the parking lot off of County Rd 52. It starts across an open field then loops through a wooded area. The wooded area takes you along Cedar Creek and has wooden benches to sit and enjoy the surroundings. This trail is mostly flat and is great for dogs.
Land Manager:  City of Greenfield, IN
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Deam Lake State Recreation Area
Land Manager:  USFS - Hoosier National Forest Office

The east/west portion of this trail (on the southern end) is an abandoned county road. The northern loop trail is a typical well-cut HHC trail that in combination with the road nets about 3 miles. The trail leaves the parking area (behind the gate) to your left; the county road is to your right. The county road has several offshoots on it that get a little confusing on the return, as it was not blazed. Stay on the largest path and use the Hiking Project mobile app to help find your way.
A few miles east of Kokomo and west of Greentwon.

Park at the Twin Caves parking area. A short spur trail takes you down to the two twin caves, and boat tours inside the cave are available for $3 a person. The tours are short, family friendly, and worth the $3 fee. Check the Spring Mill website for a tour schedule.

Turn right at the top of the stairs to Twin Caves and head towards Bronson Cave. After about 0.1 miles, the trail comes to an overlook of Bronson Cave, which is off-limits to exploring. Parts of the cave have been known to trap spelunkers and water can rise without warning.

Continuing past Bronson Cave, the trail traverses through old timber forest and countless sinkholes, common for this area. The trail crosses two roads before meeting the Connector: Trail 4 to Trail 3 and later Connector: Spring Mill Inn to Trail 3. There is an overlook of Donaldson Cave in winter but not in summer. To get a better view of Donaldson Cave, take the connector to Trail 4 and hike down to see the cave.

Passing the connector to the Inn, the trail crosses two more roads before going through more dense forest and returning to the parking area for Twin Caves.

1.4-mile singletrack close to Purdue University.  Nestled between the golf course and Cherry lane.  Small parking area at the trailhead and/or about 200 yards away from a paved trail that runs from Purdue to West Lafayette.

The trail is generally clear as it was built for easy biking. As such, there are few roots and rocks.  A few small hills provide a bit of work and the continuous winding keep your attention.  The south side of the trail can be muddy after rain.

This is a nice beginner trail or a quick hike at lunch time.

Lookout Trail starts from the playground across from the Studebaker pine trees. It is easy to find. The trail surface is packed dirt with leaf litter. The first part of the trail is easy to follow as it travels along the side of Carlisle Hill. At the south end the trail comes upon the maple syrup operation with a sugar shack. In the late winter, there is an amazing web of plastic tubes that run from each tree to larger lines and eventually to the sugar shack. The trail will turn to the right and head up the hill. The path was difficult to follow until the well-worn rut was found that has clearly been used for decades.

Take the trail to the top of the hill. Try to imagine that this was once an operational downhill ski area from 1969 until 1986. There are remnants of the rope tows and and an alpine slide that never opened due to safety concerns. Finish the trail by heading north down the front of the hill back to the playground.
There’s a frisbee golf course here so if you’ve been meaning to try that out bring a disc. Local kids flock here in the winter for a sled run.

Trail 1 is one of the better trails in the Hickory Ridge system. It is farther from the Horse Camp, so it receives less horse traffic. Its northern terminus is off Cornett Rd. near its intersection with W. County Road 760 N. The trail heads to the west where it crosses Callahan Branch and climbs over the ridge, then descends to cross Callahan Branch again and intersect with Hickory Ridge Trail 14, Hickory Ridge Trail 15, and Hickory Ridge Trail 17. 

It climbs steeply out of the valley, reaches its highest point just before it loops back towards the east, crosses a pipeline right-of-way, gradually descends, and intersects with Hickory Ridge Trail 17 again at its southern terminus, near the eastern terminus of Hickory Ridge Trail 17.

Park at the Runnels Shelter parking lot. The trailhead is easy to find behind the shelter. The trail surface is packed dirt with leaf litter. The trail will split almost immediately into several trails. Take the right onto the Big Tree Trail. There is a sign post. The trail will wind through a climax beech / maple forest with interspersed tulip poplars. The trees are very large with a nice open understory. The trail will pass the junctions for the Lower Big Tree Trail as it turns to the north. The trail ends at the junction with the Raccoon Run Trail. It is recommended when taking this trail to add Lower Big Tree Trail to the outing.

Bendix Woods County Park was once owned by the famed Studebaker Automobile Corporation. 840 acres were purchased in 1926 and became the first automobile proving grounds in America. Various road conditions were simulated to test their cars. Although it was a testing facility, Studebaker maintained the grounds as a natural area. In 1938, they planted 8,000 pine trees that spell the their name "STUDEBAKER" when viewed from the air. You can still see it today on the map above running north-south. The trees were added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1985.

The proving grounds were sold to the Bendix corporation in 1963, which in turn donated 195 acres to St. Joseph County to establish the county park. The rest of the acreage is still being used as automotive proving grounds today. Bendix used the grounds until 1996, selling it to Bosch who then sold the land to Navistar in 2015.

For more information about Bendix Woods, visit the park's website.

This is a popular trail, and the parking lot can only accommodate a half dozen cars, so be prepared to go elsewhere if the parking lot is too full. Nearby Bonneyville Mill County Park is a good alternative destination.
Land Manager:  USFS - Hoosier National Forest Office
Park at Imagination Glen.
Wear blaze orange during hunting seasons. Permits are needed for horses and mountain bikes.
This is a short, easy hike with a couple of established overlooks. There are a lot of birds to see, as well as beaver habitats to discover.
Deam Lake charges an entrance fee except during low, cold weather, season.

This trail is the shortest on the property. The trail is only about a half mile long with just a few small hills. There are views of the creek below and no forks to get lost on. This simple path is great for small children, and then they can play on the playground by the entrance on the slide and swings.

This trail starts across the road in front of the Nature Center. This trail passes between the two one-way sections of park roadway, and runs along the ridgetop over a large rock outcrop, and ends after passing through a short narrow crack in the rock. You'll likely have seen the rock passage on your drive to the Nature Center. You can return to the nature center via the same trail, or on the roadway to get a better look at the rock outcropping from below.
Restrooms and water are available at the Nature Center when open.

Trail 19 is a little bit off on its lonesome. It does not connect directly to any other trails. Connections must be made via the gravel roads at each end of the trail. The eastern terminus is just west of Maumee, IN off of N. County Road 1190 W.  Its western terminus is off of the road named (in different places, it's unclear where the name change actually occurs) County Road 1460 W. or County Road 1500 W.

Head to the north at the western terminus and you can head towards the Hickory Ridge Lookout Tower. Head south and you can connect to other trails in the Hickory Ridge trail system.
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation
This paved trail is a converted railroad that takes you past several current and past locations related to the car industry in Kokomo while connecting newer businesses starting to fill the corridor.
There is no parking on Indiana State Road 234 for Pine Hills Nature Preserve.

This segment begins near a parking area and follows a gravel service road for a short while. Keep a lookout for the trail split on the left/east side, and follow the red diamond blazes. This trail passes through an area that experienced a "prescribed burn" in April 2019. The mature trees clearly survived the burn, but charred remains of under-story brush is evident and burn marks apparent on the trunks of larger trees. The trail passes mostly through hardwood forests and some areas of pine trees.
Restrooms are available when the Nature Center is open.
Parking is available near the Nature Center

A short loop near the inn. The trail connects Trail 4 and Trail 5 along Mill Creek. The hike up to the inn is surprisingly steep, no matter which end of the trail you hike up on. The section of the loop along Mill Creek is easy and scenic, being next to the water. This trail is best in the evening when the sun is going down; the raccoons come out and the people go away.

Local Club:  Hoosier Hikers Council
Land Manager:  Indiana State Forests

This trail is accessed from the Big Tree Trail. The trail surface is packed dirt with leaf litter. The trail is easily followed through the climax beech and maple forest. The trees are excellent with a great canopy. A spring comes out of the hillside forming a small creek. This trail is a recommended extension to the Big Tree Trail.

Begin Coyote Ridge at the junction of Fox Chase and Big Walnut Crossing. Head north. About halfway up the trail, you'll reach a junction with the Overlook Trail. Turning east onto this trail will lead to the Cardinal Perch, Eagle Aeire, and Pilated Peak Overlooks. Continue north along Coyote Ridge until you reach the junction of Woodland Way and Fox Chase. Proceed northeast to complete the Woodland Way loop (with optional Whitetail Ravine loop), or turn west onto Fox Chase to make a small loop back to your original junction.
Land Manager:  Indy Parks and Recreation

Paved path along the Wildcat Creek in sections. Great access point from neighborhoods near downtown into Foster Park which hosts concerts series in the park, fairs (Haynes Apperson) and other car shows/events.

Red Mill County Park is 160 acres in size and located in the glacier moraine leftover from the last ice age. The park has really nice mature forests covering the hilly terrain. Round Lake serves as the headwaters of the Little Calumet River. There are ample picnic tables and benches throughout the park.

This trail winds through nice rolling terrain under a solid canopy of mature hardwoods. It is the hilliest of the loops but still easy enough for all to navigate. The trail is never straight, which gives the feeling of being alone in the woods. Look for the trail off the Large Loop #2 trail. 

Although this is a small trail system, the trails are not consistently marked. There are infrequent signs, signs facing the wrong way and signs from an older trail system that you can see off in the woods. Also, signs are needed at the trail intersections.

Local Club:  Hoosier Hikers Council
Land Manager:  Sycamore Land Trust
This segment makes up the west spur of Anderson's White River Trail.

Red Mill County Park is 160 acres in size and located in the glacier moraine left over from the last ice age. The park has really nice mature forests covering the hilly terrain. Round Lake serves as the headwaters of the Little Calumet River. All the trails are wide with good footing. There are ample picnic tables and benches throughout the park.

One note. Although this is a small trail system, the trails are not consistently marked. There are infrequent signs, signs facing the wrong way and signs from an older trail system that you can see off in the woods. Also, signs are needed at the trail intersections. Small Loop #1 is a flat, easy loop with easy access directly from the parking lot.
Land Manager:  Indy Parks and Recreation

The trail starts from the parking lot and is well marked. The directional arrows are set up to hike the trail in a counter clockwise direction. Two trails, Rosie's Ravine Walk and the Wildflower Walk, branch off from this trail.
This trail is accessed from the Wildness Walk trail. It is a nice trail through the woods with great spring wildflowers. Take a lunch and sit at the picnic table.

Starting with a small climb, this trail heads along the hillside before returning to the start. After the first climb, the going is easy, and you'll have a relaxing hike ahead of you. There's not much to watch out for here, as the trail is smooth.
Land Manager:  Vigo County Parks and Recreation Department

This connector trail is marked with orange diamond blazes. All three of the laddered connector trails in this trail system are marked in the same color, so keep track of your progress on a map to know which connector trail you encounter.
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Interlake State Recreation Area

Trail 1 begins at its eastern terminus N. County Rd. 980 W. just north of Tipton Creek. It heads to the west, past the southern terminus of Hickory Ridge Trail 16, and ends at its western end at Trail 16 again.

It climbs gradually from east to west until you reach a pipeline right-of-way. When the trail crosses the ROW, it descends steeply to its western terminus.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

Local Club:  Hoosier Hikers Council
Land Manager:  Sycamore Land Trust
Beginning at the parking area for the Spring Mill Village, this trail climbs a bluff and heads straight to a picnic area and the nature center.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Potato Creek State Park
May close during flooding events. Do not go around floodwaters.

This short trail is characterized by the abundance of birds and cattails found in this area. Most of the trail is along the lake allowing opportunities for fishing and wildlife viewing. The trail ends near campsite 194, in a non-electric section of the campground.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Turkey Run State Park

Trail 2 is used to connect N. County Road 1290 W. with Hickory Ridge Trail 16. Its northern terminus begins on a ridgeline and descends that ridge, crosses a valley, and climbs back out of that valley. It intersects with Hickory Ridge Trail 16 on top of a different ridge.
The preserve parking lot is in a neighborhood and can be difficult to find. Look for street signs that have trailhead signs with directional arrows. No restrooms and no water.
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation
Starting from the parking lot, this trail leaves the powerlines to dive into the forest on its way to the Eagle Creek Trail. Along the way, it makes a junction with Trail 2, at which it heads left.
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation

No access fee. Open daily from dawn to dusk. Pets permitted on a leash (6' or shorter). No bicycles or motorized vehicles. Year round porta-potty. No potable water source.

This loop trail winds through the woods and next to several ponds. There are a few wooden platforms from which you can get a better view of the ponds. This trail does, however, have a lot of bugs. I would definitely recommend bringing mosquito spray.
Land Manager:  City of Fishers, IN - Parks & Recreation

Land Manager:  DNR- Chain O Lakes State Park

A lollipop loop that starts at the Stanley schoolhouse parking area, travels through the Henslow's sparrow restoration area open field, through a wetland, and to the top of a wooded glacial esker, before circling Kreiger Lake, a beautiful small kettle lake.
Trail 6 can be accessed from the cabins, the campground, the Glacier Ridge shelter, or the Dock Lake boat ramp. Follows the shoreline of both Dock and Long lakes, and the channel between the two.
Begins at Sand Lake fishing pier, nears Weber Lake and follows part of Bowen Lake. It winds through lowlands, along two different channels, and through an upland forest.
Trail 2 begins on the parking lot on the north shore of Bowen Lake, drops down and follows the lakeshore through the woods and returns to the parking lot.
A self-guided nature trail (brochure provided) that begins at the Stanley Schoolhouse, circles Finster Lake and crosses a glacial kame, and returns to the schoolhouse.

Park on the south shore at the Nature Center/Concessions, or on the north shore at the kayak launch. The trail follows the shoreline of Sand Lake while crossing two channels and passing the boat launch, canoe rentals, two fishing piers, and a swimming beach.

This trail is just off the road of a small commercial district. It's partially shady and a very easy dirt path around a small lake. People sometimes fish near the island at the north end of the lake, but otherwise it's quiet and you won't see anyone.

The trail begins at the Nature Center in tandem with Trail 2. After a short distance, Trail 1 splits to the left/south and quickly passes Dillard Spring. Continuing through the valley, the trail is a bit eroded and crosses some drainage systems, passes a spur-trail to the Fisherman Campground, then draws close to a protected cove of Patoka Lake. A short spur extends toward the cove for a closer view of the lake. Continuing around the bend, Trail 1 links back up with Trail 2.
Land Manager:  Indy Parks and Recreation

This trail is wide and travels through open rolling hills, making it excellent for cross-country skiing in winter. Listed as 2.5 miles, if you start and end in the parking area it is actually 3.5 miles.
This path starts at the East Trailhead and goes past the northwest short of the Kesling Wetland and then passes the southeast shore of Keeling Wetland before ending back at the starting point.

This path starts west at the South Trailhead before turning north to Onion Bottom. It then heads west to follow the south and west sides of Shew Wetland, before turning east to partially follow the south shore of Bear Lake. The path then heads South again back to the starting point.
All visitors in the field must wear fluorescent orange hat or vest during allowed deer and turkey hunting seasons.  The seasons are shortened durations from the state-defined seasons.

This trail is fairly flat making it a great option for an easy hike. The trail is on multiple surfaces, and is singletrack for more than half. You'll still encounter some grass on the newer sections. Additionally, it has some asphalt connections.

trail_name: Knobstone Trail (KT): Delaney Park Loop, West

A short, easy trail that connects the campground to the beach.

The Indiana Dunes State Park was established in 1925 and contains 2,182 acres of land. The park is home to the tallest sand dunes in the area and approach 200 feet in height. The park contains a diverse range of beach, forest, and wetland habitats. As a result, this is an incredible spot for birding. There are three miles of pristine beaches along the Lake Michigan shoreline. 

Visit the State Park website for information on programs, camping, and other activities.

This trail connects the Calumet Dunes Paved Trail and the Glenwood Dunes Trail to the Indiana Dunes National Park's Dunewood Campground. Park at the USGS research station (old visitor center) located at the corner of Kemil Road and U.S. Highway 12. The paved parking lot holds 35 cars. Begin the hike by hiking south on the Calumet Dunes Paved Trail. 

The Dunewood Trace Campground Trail breaks off to the east within a tenth of a mile. The trail is 4.4 miles roundtrip to the campground and back. The trail surface is a mixture or packed dirt and loose sand. Please be careful on this section of trail as it runs on the rural road 375 East. There is no sidewalk or protected path. As you get close to the campground, look for remnants of an old golf course.

The paved parking lot holds 35 cars. It is located at the intersection U.S. Highway 12 and Kemil Road (East State Park Road 300E). This is the location of the old visitor center. Use insect repellent, wear long sleeves, and tuck long pants into socks to avoid ticks and poison ivy.
This very short trail connects the campground to the Nature Center. From it you can access Trails 7, 8, 9, and 10 to start your exploration of Indiana Dunes State Park.
Clifty Inn and a short drive to town is all the food and entertainment you could look for off trail.

This is a short hike around the picnic area with lots of trees on the sides of the woods. It seems to be used very infrequently. It does merge with the Schoen Creek Trail for a few hundred feet at the back of the trail and then bears left away from it.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - Interlake State Recreation Area
Land Manager:  Indy Parks and Recreation

Beginning by the Silver Creek Boat Ramp, the trail crosses the main road and immediately goes uphill to the Veterans Vista. This vista is best during winter months and offers better views of the lake when there are less leaves. The trail turns left and goes through a rotation of dense forest and open fields for the remainder of the hike. 

There are three road crossings in total and the trail passes by the family cabins. The last half mile of the trail passes through flat lowlands near the lakeshore and is frequently muddy after rains.
This is the trail that runs around the outside of the park.

This trail segment connects the south parking lot to the Cowles Bog trail system. See the Cowles Bog Trail page for the featured hike at Cowles Bog. Use insect repellent, wear long sleeves, and tuck long pants into socks to avoid ticks and poison ivy. 

This parking lot also serves the Calumet Rail Trail and Porter Brickyard Bike Trail.

Indiana Dunes National Park (formerly national lakeshore) was established to preserve portions of the Indiana Dunes and other areas of scenic, scientific, historic and recreational value. Up to two million annual visitors enjoy the park's 15,000 acres of wetlands, prairies, sand dunes, oak savannas, forests, and historic sites. The park's 15 miles of beaches hug the southern shore of Lake Michigan from Gary, IN, to Michigan City, IN. For more information, visit  nps.gov/indu or  facebook.com/IndianaDunesNPS.

Beginning near the campground gatehouse, this trail crosses the dam of a small wildlife pond and returns through wooded terrain to the campground. This is a good trail for observing pond life and white-tailed deer.

This short trail could almost not be a trail, it’s so short, but it saves a long trip along the road going to the Orchard Shelter House. The trail has two medium-length bridges, and it is very steep at the point closest to camp. It received heavy damage in a storm a few years ago and, while clear of trees, it’s still a bit rough.
This .4 mile trail begins a short ways from the Youth Tent Area parking spaces and takes you to an old cemetery. Please be respectful if you plan to visit.

This .3 mile loop that starts and ends in the Cherry Hill Shelter Picnic Area parking lot.  You'll work your way along the edges of the grove until you reach the doubletrack that leads into the forest and back again.  The first entrance is located behind the swing set.
Land Manager:  IN DNR - McCormick's Creek State Park

Despite the name "Scenic" Trail, this trail is arguably the least scenic at Brookville Lake and follows an abandoned road through dense woodlands and an occasional field.

Beginning at Garr Hill boat ramp, the road crosses a bridge with a nice rocky creek, and immediately climbs a 300 foot hill. Once at the top, the trail is the same from here on. The crumbling road features lots of twists and turns through the woods. It's not uncommon to see wildlife along this trail due to its isolation.

Perhaps the only thing of interest on this trail is the large wooden bridge near the southern terminus of the trail. It comes out of nowhere and is very cool looking.
There are no services on the way, and the trail is often muddy.

The nearest parking lots are located at the intersection of U.S. Highway 20 with Brummitt Road and at the intersection of U.S. Highway 12 with Kemil Road (East State Park Road (300 E). Hike the Glenwood Dunes Trail to access this extension.

The trail winds through ancient forested dunes and connects with the main Glenwood Dunes Trail. The trail surface is a mixture of packed dirt and loose sand. The roundtrip distance from the train station to the Glenwood Dunes Trail and back is 2.6 miles. Use insect repellent, wear long sleeves, and tuck long pants into socks to avoid ticks and poison ivy.

Indiana Dunes National Park (formerly national lakeshore) was established to preserve portions of the Indiana Dunes and other areas of scenic, scientific, historic and recreational value. Up to two million annual visitors enjoy the park's 15,000 acres of wetlands, prairies, sand dunes, oak savannas, forests, and historic sites. The park's 15 miles of beaches hug the southern shore of Lake Michigan from Gary, IN, to Michigan City, IN. For more information, visit  nps.gov/indu or  facebook.com/IndianaDunesNPS.
There is no water or restrooms. Wear blaze orange during deer and turkey seasons. Ticks are abundant in the summer.

This short loop is wheelchair-accessible and strolls through Donaldson Woods Nature Preserve. The trail begins and ends at the Virgil I. Grissom Memorial and Museum, dedicated to Gus Grissom from nearby Mitchell, Indiana. He was the second American in space and the museum features his space suit and Gemini III space capsule. The museum is free, but there is an entrance fee into Spring Mill State Park.

This short loop connects with part of Templeton Creek Trail to make a self-guided loop through mature woods. There is parking and brochures available by Mounds Campground shelter located at the southernmost point of this trail. This trail is mostly gravel, and as of spring 2019, it seems like there are some repairs taking place on this loop.
A mix of packed dirt trails and fields through a frisbee golf course. If you're up to the task of watching out for flying discs, then it's also a nice area to hike, especially during off-peak hours.

This short loop trail runs off the Raccoon Run Trail. It can accessed from the Deneve Shelter area or from the Big Tree Trail near the Hardwoods Shelter. The surface is packed dirt with leaf litter. The trail is flat and easy.

The trail runs from a loop off the Raccoon Run Trail. The surface is packed dirt with leaf litter. The trail is nice for young kids playing at the Devere Shelter and Ohtahnagon picnic area. Although there are trail markers, this trail is very hard to follow. The trail map is not drawn to scale. The good news is that if you do get lost, you'll find your way in a matter of minutes. 

Bendix Woods County Park was once owned by the famed Studebaker Automobile Corporation. 840 acres were purchased in 1926 and became the first automobile proving grounds in America. Various road conditions were simulated to test their cars. Although it was a testing facility, Studebaker maintained the grounds as a natural area. In 1938, they planted 8,000 pine trees that spell the their name "STUDEBAKER" when viewed from the air. You can still see it today on the map above running north-south. The trees were added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1985. 

The proving grounds were sold to the Bendix corporation in 1963, which in turn donated 195 acres to St. Joseph County to establish the county park. The rest of the acreage is still being used as automotive proving grounds today. Bendix used the grounds until 1996, selling it to Bosch who then sold the land to Navistar in 2015. 

For more information about Bendix Woods, visit the following website: sjcparks.org/bendix.html.

A 1.4-mile trail that begins off of CR 125S and takes you along Stonehenge and Sprigtail Lakes. The trail terminates at an intersection with Timberdoodle Path, which can take you back to a parking area or access other trails. 

The going is flat, and the trail is pleasant, with some great opportunities to enjoy local wildlife.
Begins at the Poplar Grove picnic area and continues past the water tower. Overlooks a small stream, which it eventually crosses. Returns to picnic area after ascending a steep hill.

It crosses or follows several roads along its length. Beginning at the intersection of Hickory Ridge Trail 2 and Hickory Ridge Trail 10, one can follow it clockwise or counter-clockwise. Following it clockwise, you'll first cross Hickory Grove Rd. It parallels McPike Branch Rd. for about a mile before turning north and crossing that road. A horse trail will branch off to the left.

Trail 4 will begin to loop around to the east and you'll pass the intersection with Hickory Ridge Trail 18. Trail 4 will then begin to loop back towards the south, and will cross Hickory Grove Rd. before intersecting with Trail 10 again.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

The southern terminus of Trail 2 begins off of Horse Camp Rd. near Norman, IN. It heads southwest for a while until shortly after it reaches Hickory Ridge Trail 5, where it begins a winding on a generally northwest track. Along this course, it intersects with the ends of Hickory Ridge Trail 6, Hickory Ridge Trail 7, Hickory Ridge Trail 8, and Hickory Ridge Trail 9 as you travel northwest. At its northern end, it intersects with Hickory Ridge Trail 10 and Hickory Ridge Trail 4.

This trail has a number of short, but steep climbs and descents.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

This .8 mile trail starts and ends off the Tinderdoodle Path, making for a pleasant detour. It also intersects with the Turtle Trail.  Most of the trail travels through the Sky Dance Prairie, making it a perfect place to view the birds that call the area home.

Trail 3 can be used to create a loop along with Hickory Ridge Trail 1, as it intersects it at each end. It also intersects with Trail 11, Trail 12, and Trail 13.

Traveling counter-clockwise on this trail, after intersections with Trails 11, 12, and 13, you'll intersect with the gravel Horse Camp Rd. At this intersection, head east for approx 700 ft and Trail 3 will pick up again on the north side of the road. The trail will begin to loop back around to the west, and will cross the intersection of Hickory Grove Rd. and Horse Camp Rd. near the other end of Trail 12 before intersecting with Trails 1 and 10.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

This is an easy, relatively flat trail that is not used very often. The trail is home to an old-growth forest where many large trees live. The trail is not well kept through the year, so it's best visited in fall, winter and early spring when the vegetation has receded.

Trail 2 is a connector trail that links N. County Road 1190 W. to the south of Maumee with N. County Road 1200 W. It passes through a couple of clearings along its course with wildlife viewing opportunities.

It is sometimes used by hikers who wish to connect the Nebo Ridge Trail with trails in the Hickory Ridge trail system.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.
Land Manager:  Indy Parks and Recreation
Wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

Trail 5 begins off of Henderson Creek Rd. and connects to Hickory Ridge Trail 2. It is a short trail and has no other intersections. It is mostly a ridgeline trail, but it does descend some before it reaches Trail 2.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

Trail 1 connects from N. County Rd. 1290 W. (Polk Patch Rd.) near Norman, IN with Hickory Ridge Trail 16 near Callahan Branch. It is more difficult than Trail 14, owing to the bigger and steeper hills. The steepest climbs on Trail 1 are near the western end. 

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

Trail 10 runs east-west and connects Hickory Ridge Trail 2 with Hickory Ridge Trail 1 and Hickory Ridge Trail 3. It passes to the south of the Hickory Grove Church.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime

Trail 1 connects Hickory Ridge Trail 3 near the intersections with Hickory Ridge Trail 11 and Hickory Ridge Trail 12 with N. County Road 1290 W. (Polk Patch Rd.). It generally heads downhill from its southeastern terminus with the road and its northwestern terminus with Trail 3. Part of that hill is rather steep.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

This well-traveled trail spur branches off of the Garden Rock Loop trail near the Nature Center.  A signpost marks the trail split. The trail ends near the lakeshore where you can meander around the end of the peninsula to view the lake.  There was likely an old homesite nearby as a fencepost can be seen, a yucca plant, gnarly oak tree, and what is presumably a covered well.

Trail 1 is an east-west connector that bisects the loop created by Hickory Ridge Trail 1 and Hickory Ridge Trail 3. After beginning at its western terminus at Trail 1, it crosses Horse Camp Rd. and heads to the east. Near its midpoint, there is a fairly steep but short descent before it levels off to intersect with Trail 3.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime

Trail 7 is a short trail that connects from Hickory Ridge Trail 2 at its southwestern terminus to Hickory Ridge Trail 1 at its northeastern terminus near the Horse Camp. It is a ridgeline trail with little elevation change.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

This trail is not on park maps but there are signs located at the trailheads. The northern trailhead is in a grassy area off Mounds Beach Road. The southern trailhead is to the left of the camp store.
As of October 2021, the trail is fairly overgrown in sections.

Trail 1 begins its western terminus off of Horse Camp Rd. near where Hickory Ridge Trail 3 crosses. It generally parallels Horse Camp Rd. to the east before turning south to intersect with Hickory Ridge Trail 3 near Hickory Ridge Trail 11.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime.

Trail 9 is another trail that connects from Hickory Ridge Trail 2 at its southwestern terminus to Hickory Ridge Trail 1 at its northeastern terminus near the Horse Camp. It trends generally downhill from the southwest to the northeast.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime

Trail 1 connects N. County Rd. 1290 W. (Polk Patch Rd.) with Hickory Ridge Trail 16 near Callahan Branch.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

Hickory Ridge Trail 1 parallels Horse Camp Road and has a trailhead at the Horse Camp.

It intersects with several other trails in the Hickory Ridge network, including Hickory Ridge Trail 3 and Hickory Ridge Trail 6 at its southern terminus, and Hickory Ridge Trail 7, Hickory Ridge Trail 8, and Hickory Ridge Trail 9 to the west as you go north, Hickory Ridge Trail 11 to the east, and Hickory Ridge Trail 3 and Hickory Ridge Trail 10 at the northern terminus.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

Trail 6 connects from Hickory Ridge Trail 2 at is southwestern terminus to its northeastern terminus with Hickory Ridge Trail 1 and Hickory Ridge Trail 3. It is mostly a ridgeline trail.

Trails nearest the Horse Camp receive higher horse traffic and, therefore, have more horse bogs. They are better to hike in the wintertime when frozen.

Trail 9 is technically a connector trail and is often forgotten about at Shades State Park. The only point of interest on this trail is the pond. Shortly after passing the pond heading west, Trail 6 branches off to the right. After that, Trail 9 Connector branches off to the left, heading towards the Youth Tent Campground. Continue straight to access the campground road, where the trail ends. To get to the campground, take the campground road straight ahead.

Button Bush Woods is a wooded area home to Button Bush Trees. The are is a historic area once used by early settlers to the area and Native Americans. Close to the original George Rogers Clark home site and the original settlement of Clarksville, IN.

The trail follows the South Shore Railroad tracks and NIPSCO power lines. There is no shade. The trail can be impassible (i.e. wet shoes) due to standing water along much of the trail that can be 4-6" deep in spots. The trail is not suitable for road bikes.

There are parking lots at both ends. The paved parking lot on the west end has 18 spots (1 handicap) and is located at U.S. Highway 12 and Mineral Springs Road. There are year round porta-potties. There is no potable water source. The paved parking lot on the east end has 8 spaces with no restrooms or potable water source. There are also restrooms and potable water at the Dune Park and Beverly Shores South Shore railroad stations.

This trail does connect many trail systems. The west end parking lot connects to the Porter Brickyard Trail and the Cowles Bog South Access (Greenbelt Trail). There is access to the Dunes Kankakee Trail and Indiana Dunes State Park trail system at the Dunes Park train station. At East State Park Road (Kemil Road or 300E), there is access across U.S. Highway 12 to the Glenwood Dunes Trail and Calumet Dunes Paved Trail. At Broadway Avenue (Beverly Shores), there is access to the Great Marsh Trail and Dunewood Trace Campground Trail. On the east end, the parking lot is on U.S. Highway 12 and is close to the Mt. Baldy Summit Trail.
